nodes.text: A systematic literature review can map and synthesize interpretability and explainability methods applied to predictive process monitoring (PPM), identify trends, gaps and challenges, and produce a structured agenda and guidance for future research and practice
We conducted a PRISMA-based systematic literature review covering roughly the past decade (including 2025 works) to collect, screen and synthesize studies on XAI and interpretable ML for PPM

Definitions and formal foundations for PPM were established: formal event, trace, event log, feature extraction, labeling, supervised learning and common PPM tasks (outcome, next-event, PPI, remaining time)

We distinguished intrinsically interpretable models (trees, rules, regression, Bayesian, k-NN, GAM) from black-box models (deep learning, gradient boosting, random forests) and defined local vs global and model-agnostic vs model-specific post-hoc explanation methods

Selection protocol: multi-database queries, inclusion/exclusion criteria (peer-reviewed, PPM task, XAI method, event logs, English), forward/backward search, template-driven data extraction and thematic synthesis aligned to eight RQs
Corpus: 1,415 records identified, 136 full texts screened, 107 studies included in final synthesis (journals, conferences, arXiv); most publications from 2020 onward with a 2020+ spike
Extracted taxonomy and mapping: application domains, benchmark datasets, prediction tasks, interpretable model families, post-hoc techniques and evaluation paradigms were catalogued and compared

Primary contributions reported: comprehensive panorama linking domains/datasets/tasks to XAI techniques; unified taxonomy and critical appraisal; systematic evaluation audit; evidence-based research agenda; practitioner decision-support guidance
Data extraction and synthesis employed template analysis aligned to eight research questions (RQ1–RQ8) to ensure each theme directly addressed the RQs

Dataset and domain findings: BPIC suite dominates (used in 57% of studies), with finance, healthcare, customer support and manufacturing most represented; limited diversity of public logs biases domain coverage and generalizability
Task distribution: process outcome prediction is most common (~60% of studies), next-event prediction and time-related PPI predictions follow; classification tasks dominate over regression

Model usage trends: intrinsically interpretable models (decision trees, Bayesian nets, logistic regression, rule-based) remain widely used, but there is a shift toward black-box models (DL, GBMs, RFs) for higher predictive accuracy

Post-hoc explanation methods reported include local methods (LIME, SHAP, ICE, LRP, counterfactuals) and global methods (PDP, aggregated SHAP, feature importance, surrogate models); methods differ by scope, model-relation and output format (numeric, textual, rule-based, visual)

Finding on transferability: heavy reliance on a few public logs (BPIC variants, Helpdesk, Sepsis, Production) facilitates benchmarking but constrains assessment of cross-domain robustness and external validity

Evaluation gap: most studies prioritize predictive performance; many omit formal explanation evaluation—only a minority perform quantitative or qualitative assessments and very few combine both or perform human-grounded studies

Research agenda and open challenges: rigorous evaluation frameworks (quantitative+qualitative), encoding impact, object-centric process mining (OCPM) explanations, streaming/real-time explainability, uncertainty/ privacy/fairness integration, LLM-driven conversational explanations and multi-modal explainers
